docs.title: Hello Data Points 👋
docs.text:
Description

A small, fast CLI to display styled file/folder trees — perfect for documenting project structure, exporting to Markdown, or quickly inspecting repos.

docs.title: Install
docs.text:
Install

From PyPIFrom UVFrom SourceWindows PowerShell 
# From PyPI 
pip install show-file-tree

# From UV
uv pip install show-file-tree
From Source
# From source (dev)
git clone https://github.com/Rudra-G-23/show-file-tree.git

cd show-file-tree
python -m venv .venv
Windows PowerShell
.venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1
pip install -e ".[all]"

docs.text:

docs.title: 😎 Why use show-file-tree?
docs.text:
• Fast, memory-safe traversal — suitable for large directories.
  • Pretty terminal output — icons, counts, human-readable sizes.
  • Powerful filtering — globs, mtime/ctime windows.
  • Markdown export — create readable project documentation automatically.
  • Themes & ASCII fallback — works in CI or minimal terminals.
  • and many more .....

docs.title: --exclude / -e
docs.text:
Info

  • The --exclude flag allows you to skip specific files or directories when building the tree.
  • You can use glob patterns (wildcards) to match multiple paths.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Usage

Only *log files
# Exclude all log files
show-file-tree  --exclude "*.log"
A specific folder
# Exclude a specific folder
show-file-tree  --exclude "tests/*"

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Example how this command works

Files in project
src/
tests/
README.md
debug.log
config.yaml
Command
show-file-tree  --exclude "*.log" --exclude "tests/*"
Output
├── 📁 src
├── README.md
└── config.yaml # (1)!
  1. debug.log and tests/ are excluded from the tree.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Tip

  • Multiple --exclude flags can be combined for fine-grained filtering.
  • Combine with --include to focus on specific file types while ignoring others: Both
    show-file-tree  --include "*.py" --exclude "tests/*"
  • Works with --format md to generate filtered Markdown documentation.

docs.title: --include / -i
docs.text:
Info

  • The --include flag allows you to show only specific files or directories when building the tree.
  • You can use glob patterns (wildcards) to match multiple paths.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Usage

Only python files
# Include only Python files
show-file-tree  --include "*.py"
All markdown files
# Include all Markdown files
show-file-tree  --include "*.md"

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Example

Files in project
src/
tests/
README.md
debug.log
config.yaml
Command
show-file-tree . --include "*.py" --include "*.md"
Output
├── 📁 src
│   └── main.py
└── README.md

Only *.py and *.md files are included in the tree.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Tip

  • Multiple --include flags can be combined to include several file types.
  • Combine with --exclude to refine filtering: Filtering
    show-file-tree  --include "*.py" --exclude "tests/*"
  • Works with --format md to generate filtered Markdown documentation.

docs.title: Creation Time Filters
docs.text:
Info

show-file-tree supports filtering by file creation time using the following flags:

  • --ctime-after <YYYY-MM-DD> — Include only files created after the specified date.
  • --ctime-before <YYYY-MM-DD> — Include only files created before the specified date.

These filters are useful for auditing recent changes or generating snapshots of files created within a specific period.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Usage

AfterBeforeCombine both Include files created after a certain date
show-file-tree  --ctime-after 2025-01-01
Include files created before a certain date
show-file-tree  --ctime-before 2025-06-01
Combine
show-file-tree  --ctime-after 2025-01-01 --ctime-before 2025-06-01 # (1)!
  1. Only files created between Jan 1, 2025 and Jun 1, 2025 will appear.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Example

Files in projectCommandOutput 
file1.py   (created 2024-12-10)
file2.py   (created 2025-02-15)
file3.py   (created 2025-05-20)
file4.py   (created 2025-07-01)

show-file-tree  --ctime-after 2025-01-01 --ctime-before 2025-06-01

├── file2.py
└── file3. # (1)!
  1. Files outside the date range are excluded.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Tip

  • Dates must be in YYYY-MM-DD format.
  • Combine with other flags like --max-depth or --sort for precise views: Advanced Features
    show-file-tree  --ctime-after 2025-01-01 --max-depth 2 --sort name
  • Works with --format md to export time-filtered Markdown trees.

docs.title: Modification Time Filters
docs.text:
Info

show-file-tree supports filtering by file modification time using the following flags:

  • --mtime-after <YYYY-MM-DD> — Include only files modified after the specified date.
  • --mtime-before <YYYY-MM-DD> — Include only files modified before the specified date.

These filters are useful for tracking recent changes or documenting updates within a specific timeframe.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Usage

AfterBeforeCombine Include files modified after a certain date
show-file-tree  --mtime-after 2025-01-01
Include files modified before a certain date
show-file-tree  --mtime-before 2025-06-01
Combine both
show-file-tree  --mtime-after 2025-01-01 --mtime-before 2025-06-01 # (1)!
  1. Only files modified between Jan 1, 2025 and Jun 1, 2025 will appear.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Example

Files in projectCommandOutput 
file1.py   (modified 2024-12-10)
file2.py   (modified 2025-02-15)
file3.py   (modified 2025-05-20)
file4.py   (modified 2025-07-01)

show-file-tree  --mtime-after 2025-01-01 --mtime-before 2025-06-01

├── file2.py
└── file3.py # (1)!
  1. Files outside the date range are excluded.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Tip

  • Dates must be in YYYY-MM-DD format.
  • Combine with other flags like --max-depth, --sort, or --count for more detailed views: Advanced Command
    show-file-tree  --mtime-after 2025-01-01 --max-depth 2 --count
  • Works with --format md to export modification-time filtered Markdown trees.

docs.title: ✨ Key Features of show-file-tree
docs.text:
1. Styled Tree Visualization – Display folder and file structures in a clean, readable tree format.
  2. Color Themes & Icons – Choose from themes (colorful, monokai, light, nocolor) with or without icons.
  3. Depth Control – Limit recursion depth with -d / --max-depth for concise trees.
  4. Size & Count Display – Show file sizes and directory item counts.
  5. Sorting & Ordering – Sort output by name or size, in ascending or descending order.
  6. Filtering Support – Include/exclude files with glob patterns and time-based filters (mtime, ctime).
  7. Gitignore Awareness – Automatically respects .gitignore (or bypass with --no-gitignore).
  8. Markdown Export – Export the entire file tree to a .md file for documentation.
  9. Hidden Files Option – Easily toggle visibility of hidden files and directories.
  10. Top N Insights – Show top N largest or most recently modified files in the tree.

docs.title: --count
docs.text:
Info

  • The --count flag displays the number of files and directories inside each folder in the tree.
  • This makes it easy to see folder contents at a glance without expanding everything.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Usage

show-file-tree  --count

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Example

Without --countWith --count 
├── 📁 docs
│   └── readme.md
├── 📁 src
│   └── main.py
└── LICENSE

├── 📁 docs (3f, 2d)
│   └── readme.md
├── 📁 src (5f, 1d)
└── LICENSE

Legend

  • 3f = 3 files
  • 2d = 2 subdirectories

docs.title: Tip
docs.text:
Tip

  • Combine --count with other display flags: 
    show-file-tree  --count --size --theme monokai
  • This shows folder counts, file sizes, and a colored theme in one view.

docs.title: Why it’s useful
docs.text:
Abstract

  • Quickly assess folder contents without opening directories.
  • Helpful in documentation, code reviews, or project analysis.
  • Works well with --max-depth for summarized folder overviews.

docs.title: --format
docs.text:
Info

The --format flag lets you choose how the tree is displayed or exported.

  • tree (default) — Display the tree in the terminal with optional icons, counts, and sizes.
  • md — Export the tree to a Markdown file for documentation purposes.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Usage

Terminal tree (default)
show-file-tree .
Export to Markdown
show-file-tree --format md /path/to/project  # (1)!
  1. This creates a file named <rootname>-file-tree.md in your current directory.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Example

Terminal output (--format tree)Markdown export (--format md) tree
├── 📁 docs
│   └── readme.md
├── 📁 src
│   └── main.py
└── LICENSE
md
# Project Tree
- docs/
  - readme.md
- src/
  - main.py
- LICENSE

docs.title: Tip
docs.text:
Tip

--format md with other flags like --size or --count to generate rich, documented project trees.

docs.title: --no-icons
docs.text:
Info

The --no-icons flag disables file/folder icons in the output. This is useful if:

  • You’re working in a terminal that doesn’t support Unicode emojis.
  • You prefer a plain ASCII output.
  • You want minimal, icon-free Markdown exports.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Usage

show-file-tree  --no-icons

docs.title: Behind the scenes
docs.text:
By default, show-file-tree uses a rich icon mapping for file types:

Icon/Emojis used in tree File Type / Extension Icon Meaning / Notes Folders 📁 / 📂 Closed / Open folder Generic file 📄 Default file .py 🐍 Python script .js, .jsx 📜 JavaScript file .ts, .tsx 📜 TypeScript file .html 🌐 HTML file .css, .scss 🎨 Stylesheet .json 📦 JSON data .md 📝 Markdown file readme.md (exact match) 📖 README file .git, .gitignore 🌿 Git-related file .png, .jpg, .jpeg, etc. 🖼️ Image files .zip, .tar, .gz, etc. 📦 Archive/compressed file .mp3, .wav 🎵 Audio file .mp4, .mov, .avi 🎬 Video file .ttf, .otf, .woff, etc. 🔤 Font files .exe, .bin (generic bin) ⚙️ Binary file .yml, .yaml, .ini, etc. 🔧 Config file .lock 🔒 Lock file license 📜 License file

If any file type is missing then you can create an Github Issues

docs.title: Tip
docs.text:
Tip

You can combine --no-icons with other options such as --size, --count, or --theme for a clean but informative tree.

docs.title: --size
docs.text:
Info

  • The --size flag shows the size of files and folders in the tree.
  • Sizes are displayed in human-readable units (KB, MB, GB) for easy reference.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Usage

# Show tree with sizes
show-file-tree  --size

docs.title: --gitignore / --no-gitignore
docs.text:
Info

  • The --gitignore flag makes show-file-tree respect .gitignore files, excluding ignored files and folders from the tree.
  • The --no-gitignore flag ignores .gitignore, showing all files and folders.

show-file-tree  --no-gitignore # (1)!
  1. All files are displayed, even if ignored in Git.
When file is ready

  • Hidden files typically start with a dot (.) on Unix-like systems (e.g., .git, .env) or are marked as hidden on Windows.

docs.text:
Info

  • The --max-depth flag limits how deep the tree will traverse into directories.
  • This is useful for large projects where you want a high-level overview without listing every nested file.

docs.title: Usage

show-file-tree  --max-depth 2

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Tip

  • Combine with --count or --size for a summarized view of folders at each depth.
  • Combine with --format md to generate Markdown documentation for only the top levels of a project.
  • Useful for quick project overviews, documentation snapshots, or CI-friendly output.
